docs.lead_paragraph: June Adler was 44 and the mother of three school-age children when she found a lump in her breast during a monthly self-examination. After learning that it was cancerous, a surgeon at a local hospital in Chicago told her she needed a mastectomy and recommended a plastic surgeon for reconstruction. Still reeling from the diagnosis, Mrs. Adler decided to get a second opinion. That doctor told a different story: Mrs. Adler's relatively small Stage 2 tumor was treatable with lumpectomy followed by radiation, he said.
docs.abstract: About half the women with early-stage breast cancer are continuing to have full mastectomies nearly ten years after National Institutes of Health expert panel concluded lumpectomy followed by radiation is preferred treatment; Dr Diana Zuckerman, in recent Journal of American Medical Women's Association article, put part of blame on doctors' preferences and on what she called their failure to communicate treatment options to patients; map (M)
